channel.title: Comments on: The Importance of Struggling

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: Thanks for letting me know man. Haha. I let them know about the typo and they've fixed it. xD
item.content:encoded: Thanks for letting me know man. Haha. I let them know about the typo and they’ve fixed it. xD

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: Well to some degree, the "struggle" I'm referring to is in regards to actually spending time to rewire those circuits in your brain. And so when you find those glaring mistakes and think about why you made them, that is considered a "struggle" if you think about it. For me, learning has always been more like. "Oh that's wrong. Okay I'll try and remember next time." Never really mulled over it or anything. Does that make sense?
item.content:encoded:
Well to some degree, the “struggle” I’m referring to is in regards to actually spending time to rewire those circuits in your brain. And so when you find those glaring mistakes and think about why you made them, that is considered a “struggle” if you think about it.
For me, learning has always been more like. “Oh that’s wrong. Okay I’ll try and remember next time.” Never really mulled over it or anything. Does that make sense?

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: You're welcome! Glad that it is helping you on your own journey!
item.content:encoded: You’re welcome! Glad that it is helping you on your own journey!

item.title: By: Paul
item.dc:creator: Paul
item.description: I don't think "deliberate learning" has to mean a struggle. I've had a lot of success finding the most glaring mistakes in a game and just thinking about why I made them. "Oh! I thought I'd win that semai because I didn't notice these stones would get into a shortage of liberties. I need to pay better attention to that." And then moving on. Under a minute of attention. Over time your brain starts fixing re-occurring themes. For example, I've been losing games lately because I get complacent with a lead and let my opponent seal off too much center territory. When that happens I try to find the key moves that gave up the lead, look at the board, and remind myself of the dangerous position that this is. Hopefully soon I'll have warning sirens going off in the back of my head before I give up a won game, rather than after =)
item.content:encoded:
I don’t think “deliberate learning” has to mean a struggle. I’ve had a lot of success finding the most glaring mistakes in a game and just thinking about why I made them. “Oh! I thought I’d win that semai because I didn’t notice these stones would get into a shortage of liberties. I need to pay better attention to that.” And then moving on. Under a minute of attention. Over time your brain starts fixing re-occurring themes.
For example, I’ve been losing games lately because I get complacent with a lead and let my opponent seal off too much center territory. When that happens I try to find the key moves that gave up the lead, look at the board, and remind myself of the dangerous position that this is. Hopefully soon I’ll have warning sirens going off in the back of my head before I give up a won game, rather than after =)

item.content:encoded: Lol, Ben, you’re on the AGA’s website and they messed up your name there. They start off by calling you Benjamin Wong in the title and then midway through the article they get your name right.

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: Thanks Todd! I certainly hope that both of us will take this to heart and apply it to our own studies. Ganbatte!
item.content:encoded: Thanks Todd! I certainly hope that both of us will take this to heart and apply it to our own studies. Ganbatte!

item.title: By: Todd Bowlby
item.dc:creator: Todd Bowlby
item.description: That is GREAT advice. It says things that I've been learning lately, but didn't have the words for. It's like, it isn't perfectionism, it's just what you do when you love something enough to want to get it right: it's how you go beyond competent and move toward talent. Great post.
item.content:encoded:
That is GREAT advice. It says things that I’ve been learning lately, but didn’t have the words for. It’s like, it isn’t perfectionism, it’s just what you do when you love something enough to want to get it right: it’s how you go beyond competent and move toward talent.
Great post.

item.title: By: Ben
item.dc:creator: Ben
item.description: Yup. And believe it or not, that is the trimmed down version. I probably could've written another 2 pages without realizing it, so I kept it as short as I possibly could.
item.content:encoded: Yup. And believe it or not, that is the trimmed down version. I probably could’ve written another 2 pages without realizing it, so I kept it as short as I possibly could.
